All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. The incumbent partner(s) will work closely with the DOH (all levels), Regional Training Centers, PEPFAR Implementing Partners, and other stakeholders to strengthen the management, coordination, planning, implementation, and M&E of comprehensive HIV/AIDS care, treatment and support activities for pediatric, adolescent, and adult populations. The goal is to improve the effectiveness and quality of HIV/AIDS programs, decrease the burden of HIV, AIDS and TB, and reduce child and maternal deaths. This award will contribute to achieving the care, support, treatment, and sustainability goals of the PEPFAR 5-year strategy.
The award will develop local indigenous capacity to: 1. Do population-based planning, target setting and M&E 2. Deliver integrated HIV/AIDS services including pediatric, PMTCT and TB services 3. Develop, implement, and maintain referral networks to improve quality of service delivery 4. Provide adequate M&E and supportive supervision systems 5. Use information as a key driver for decision making
The award will build capacity of managers and technical staff through mentoring and TA and will ensure local ownership and sustainability. The award will measure tis success based on continual review and assessment of program performance at facility, district province and national level to: a) identify gaps in service delivery; b) identify low performing entities; c) conduct root cause analysis and; d) develop quality improvement plans.
An M&E framework tracks changes in service delivery and impact of project interventions. This will enable the project to adapt, improve and innovate, so that it can support facilities, districts, provinces and national to strengthen health systems, achieve quality service delivery and improved health outcomes.
